channel.title: ASF Jira
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [FELIX-4837] Workaround for JNLPClassLoader in ShutdownHook
item.description:
This a workaround of the issue that I submitted on https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8054639

The Java Web Start classloader doesn't support to have anonymous classes or enum within the shutdown hook.

The patch below allows to stop all the bundles correctly when calling m_felix.stop() in the shutdown hook. Otherwise the framework throws an exception and do not call the bundle stop. This is a problem when each bundle write its preferences or state during the stop method.

                 
diff --git a/framework/src/main/java/org/apache/felix/framework/Felix.java b/framework/src/main/java/org/apache/felix/framework/Felix.java
index c6b305a..e44ccea 100644
--- a/framework/src/main/java/org/apache/felix/framework/Felix.java
+++ b/framework/src/main/java/org/apache/felix/framework/Felix.java
@@ -1023,7 +1023,7 @@
         {
             // Spec says stop() on SystemBundle should return immediately and
             // shutdown framework on another thread.
-            new Thread(new Runnable() {
+            Thread t = new Thread( "FelixShutdown"){
                 public void run()
                 {
                     try
@@ -1038,7 +1038,8 @@
                             ex);
                     }
                 }
-            }, "FelixShutdown").start();
+            };
+            t.start();
         }
     }

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: This patch will have no effect except for JVM launched by Java Web Start.
This issue has been fixed in Java 9. However it remains for Java 6, 7 and 8.

GitHub user nroduit opened a pull request:

https://github.com/apache/felix/pull/94

FELIX-4837 Fix issue with JNLPClassLoader in ShutdownHook

See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FELIX-4837

You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:

$ git pull https://github.com/nroduit/felix FELIX-4837

Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:

https://github.com/apache/felix/pull/94.patch

To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch
with (at least) the following in the commit message:

This closes #94

commit da14e4ab6777f789a02a6138d7936e9d34135ff2
Author: Nicolas Roduit <nicolas.roduit@gmail.com>
Date: 2017-02-19T08:31:17Z

FELIX-4837 Fix issue with JNLPClassLoader in ShutdownHook

I guess I'm not sure I understand what is going on. You are saying for some reason anonymous classes inside a shutdown hook are a problem for webstart but your fix is still instantiating an anonymous inner class (just a subclass of Thread) and the jdk bug you point to doesn't necessarily confirms anonymous classes being an issue (the comment points to a logging issue and the two referenced bugs are closed as cannot reproduce9).

Ultimately, I'm not against applying your patch on the basis that it doesn't change anything in theory and you saying it helps in Webstart but I'd really would like to understand a little better what is going on if possible.

Yes it is a very weird bug related the classloader of webstart. The anonymous class is just a consequence not the cause of the issue. The test case that I provide at https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8054639 shows the issue and now it is working as expected in Java 9. The fix in Java 9 has changed the dispose order of classloaders.

This patch is problematically the same code but allows to call felix.stop() in the shutdown hook without throwing an exception.
The fix looks a bit weird but yeah, if it works around a problem that exists in JDK 6,7 or 8 then I think we should take it. In any case it won't do any harm AFAICS.
I committed this in r1783785. Please close this issue if it works for you.

Github user asfgit closed the pull request at:

https://github.com/apache/felix/pull/94
With framework 5.6.4 get the error "felix java.lang.IllegalStateException: zip file closed" in shutdownhook.

The problem is the patch applied is different from the above one. For the current code, it must the following one:

diff --git a/framework/src/main/java/org/apache/felix/framework/Felix.java b/framework/src/main/java/org/apache/felix/framework/Felix.java
index d576d4a..2ae70c8 100644
--- a/framework/src/main/java/org/apache/felix/framework/Felix.java
+++ b/framework/src/main/java/org/apache/felix/framework/Felix.java
@@ -1023,7 +1023,7 @@
         {
             // Spec says stop() on SystemBundle should return immediately and
             // shutdown framework on another thread.
-            (new Thread("FelixShutdown") 
+            Thread t = new Thread("FelixShutdown") 
             {
                 @Override
                 public void run()
@@ -1040,7 +1040,8 @@
                             ex);
                     }
                 }
-            }).start();
+            };
+            t.start();
         }
     }

I don't work or use this project, but I did track down and workaround this webstart bug for myself. I figured I would share since this is one of the rare places that mention it. It's a nasty hack so you should only really use it if you have no other choice. Unfortunately I need it.

private static void evilEvilWebstartHack(){
//this is the hack of a lifetime here.
//there is a bug that arrived sometime around the mid java7 releases. shutdown hooks get created that shut down loggers and close down the classloader jars
//that means that anything we try to do in our shutdown hook throws an exception, but only after some random amount of time

try {
Class clazz = Class.forName("java.lang.ApplicationShutdownHooks");

Field field = clazz.getDeclaredField("hooks");
field.setAccessible(true);

Map hooks = (Map)field.get(clazz);

for (Iterator it=hooks.values().iterator(); it.hasNext(){
Thread thread=(Thread)it.next();

if ("javawsSecurityThreadGroup".equals(thread.getThreadGroup().getName()))

{ it.remove(); }

}
}
catch (Exception e) {

}
}

Thanks for sharing your experience! It is also one of the strangest and most difficult bugs I have ever dealt with.

As it has been fixed in Java 9, I will add a check:

    /**
     * @see https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8054639
     *
     */
    private static void evilEvilWebstartHack() {
        // Handle new versioning from Java 9
        String jvmVersionString = System.getProperty("java.specification.version");
        int verIndex = jvmVersionString.indexOf("1.");
        if (verIndex >= 0) {
            jvmVersionString = jvmVersionString.substring(verIndex + 2);
        }
        int major = Integer.parseInt(jvmVersionString);
        if (major < 9) {
            // this is the hack of a lifetime here.
            // there is a bug that arrived sometime around the mid java7 releases. shutdown hooks get created that
            // shutdown loggers and close down the classloader jars that means that anything we try to do in our
            // shutdown hook throws an exception, but only after some random amount of time
            try {
                Class<?> clazz = Class.forName("java.lang.ApplicationShutdownHooks");
                Field field = clazz.getDeclaredField("hooks");
                field.setAccessible(true);
                Map<?, Thread> hooks = (Map<?, Thread>) field.get(clazz);
                for (Iterator<Thread> it = hooks.values().iterator(); it.hasNext();) {
                    Thread thread = it.next();
                    if ("javawsSecurityThreadGroup".equals(thread.getThreadGroup().getName())) {
                        it.remove();
                    }
                }
            } catch (Exception e) {
                e.printStackTrace();
            }
        }
    }

I think we can close this one again. The solution seems to be a rather special case and I don't think we want to include this directly in the framework. Please create a new issue with a revised proposal if you think you have foolproof version and it is still relevant.

Yeah, it's up to you guys. It's definitely a weird one, but for whatever
it's worth this is 100% the solution. I've been using it in my product
since the last update with zero issues.

I'm using now the fix above in my code and it works perfectly well.

As it is very specific use case for Felix (Java Webstart + ShutdownHook) and this issue has been fixed in Java 9, I won't create a new issue.
